It's Time to Learn OKLCH Color â€” Feeling a bit overwhelmed by all the developments happening in CSS lately involving color? Weâ€™ve got several new options to consider such as hwb(), lab(), lch(), oklab(), and oklch() â€” here Keith makes the case for OKLCH and how to get started usingÂ it.

Keith J. Grant

Solving the CSS Layout and Source Order Disconnect â€” The CSS Working Group is seeking feedback on a proposed solution for â€œthe problem of layout methods arranging items in an order that is disconnected from the source of the documentâ€. This post explains the issue, the suggested fix, and invites yourÂ thoughts.

Rachel Andrew (Chrome Developers)

New Course by Kyle Simpson: Practical Problem Solving with Algorithms â€” Walk through four fun challenges with Kyle in this new video course. You'll learn how to apply algorithms with techniques like recursion, traversals, and acyclic paths, cover memoization to avoid garbage collection, and come away writing more performantÂ code.

Thereâ€™s a lot of depth here, some nice examples, and these techniques could prove useful for a lot of other useÂ cases.

Thomas Steiner (Google)

CSS Masking â€” A deep dive into using CSS to apply masks to images, covering how it works, along with a few use cases and accompanyingÂ examples.

Ahmad Shadeed

Everything You Need to Know About Video Storage APIs â€” A technical overview of video storage APIs, including how they work, the benefits of using them, and how to implement one for your videoÂ needs.

ImageKit sponsor

How WebAssembly is Accelerating New Web Functionality â€” WebAssembly is a portable bytecode format thatâ€™s now broadly supported and allows developers to create new capabilities and functionality on the web. It doesnâ€™t necessarily replace JavaScript, but extends itsÂ capabilities.

Thomas Nattestad (Google)

Mullvad and Tor Team Up to Release Privacy-FocusedÂ Browser â€” Mullvad is a popular privacy-focused VPN service and theyâ€™ve teamed up with the Tor Project to unveil a privacy-focused web browser designed to minimize the impact of tracking and fingerprinting. â€œYou could say itâ€™s a Tor Browser to use without the Tor Network.â€ As with Tor, itâ€™s a modified version of Firefox under theÂ hood.

Mullvad

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • A look at what's new in Chrome 112, incuding support for CSS style nesting.

  • Oliver Dunk of the Chrome Extensions Team has posted an update on the Manifest V2 to Manifest V3 transition â€“ it's taking longer than expected so Manifest V2 isn't disappearing any time soon.

  • Wes Bos quickly demonstrates what you can do with CSS color functions in a 1-minute YouTube short.

  • An interview with the creator of CSS, HÃ¥kon Wium Lie.

  • Over on Twitter, ğŸ¦ Stefan Judis notes that Firefox Nightly is the first browser shipping support for @media (scripting: none) to detect disabled JavaScript in CSS.

  • After years of work, Firefox no longer uses any XUL layouts. XUL (XML User Interface Language) was once the bedrock of Mozilla software like Firefox, but has gradually been replaced.

  • On Windows, the latest Firefox now allows users to control which third party DLLs are allowed to load into Firefox processes.

Are Safari Releases Causing 'Development Hell'? â€” Covers the troubles one team went through with the recent feature-packed Safari 16.4 release, highlighting the â€œstress and disruption it causedâ€, and why the developer believes it amounts to â€œApple having a policy of negligence towards developersâ€. Harsh words, but challenges other developers might sympathizeÂ with.

Ashley Gullen

What are Source Maps? â€” Learn how source maps can help you debug your original code instead of what was actually deployed after a buildÂ process.

Sofia Emelianova (Chrome Developers)

React Authentication, Simplified â€” In this article, we lay out a new approach to authentication (plus access control & SSO) in ReactÂ applications.

Userfront sponsor

A CSS Selector to Highlight Clickable Elements â€” An interesting, if slightly convoluted, snippet.

Seb De Deyne

â–¶Â Â Learn HTML5 and CSS3 from Scratch â€” This 11 hour epic probably isnâ€™t for you but given itâ€™s on YouTube, it could be handy for anyone you know who wants to learnÂ HTML.

John Smilga

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

Framework7 8.0: Build iOS, Android and Desktop Apps withÂ HTML â€” An open source framework for building full-featured iOS, Android and Desktop apps with Web technologies, complete with an ecosystem of plugins and tools and the ability to hook into existing front-endÂ frameworks.

Framework7

Simple Icons: 2444 Free SVG Icons for Popular Brands â€” This project that we link to every year or two continues to go from strength toÂ strength.

Simple Icons

StatiCrypt 3: Password Protect a Static HTML Page â€” We first linked this a few weeks ago, but it has since had a major release with lots of cleanups and a switch to using the more secure WebCrypto engine. LiveÂ demo.

Robin Moisson

How eBay Made Its New Accessibility Tool (And Made It Available toÂ All) â€” Several eBay teams worked together to create a Figma plug-in that makes it easy to include accessibility in a design right from theÂ start.

Dan Nosowitz (eBay)

Ellegant CSS Framework â€” Aims to provide user interaction (toggles, switches, modals, menus, etc.) with very little or no JavaScript atÂ all.

Lucas Leal

Eruda 3.0: A Console for Mobile Browsers â€” If youâ€™re in a situation where you have no access to DevTools, you can add Eruda to your page and it provides a sort of virtual devtools you can use from any browser, including onÂ mobile.

LiriLiri

Jampack: A Post-Processing Tool to Optimize StaticÂ Websites â€” Similar to a bundler or build tool, with features like image optimization, asset compression, and some code auto-fixes â€” all amounting to strong Core Web VitalsÂ scores.
